explanation: Gravitational time dilation describes how time passes more slowly in stronger gravitational fields according to general relativity. Clocks closer to massive objects run slower when observed from weaker gravitational fields, with the effect proportional to the gravitational potential difference. This phenomenon is crucial for GPS satellite accuracy, explains redshift of light escaping gravitational wells, and provides direct evidence for the equivalence principle.

assumptions.text: The mass distribution is spherically symmetric (Schwarzschild metric).
The observer is at a much larger distance from the gravitational source than the emitter.
Special relativistic effects from relative motion are negligible.
The Schwarzschild metric accurately describes spacetime around a spherically symmetric mass.
Proper time corresponds to the time measured by a local clock at rest.
Coordinate time corresponds to time measured by an observer at spatial infinity.

derivation.description: Start with the Schwarzschild metric in spherical coordinates for spacetime around a massive object.
Identify the time-time component of the metric tensor.
For a stationary observer (dr = dΩ = 0), only the time component contributes to the line element.
Define proper time through the invariant spacetime interval.
Substitute the metric component into the proper time expression.
Simplify using the sign convention for timelike intervals.
Take the square root to get the relationship between proper time and coordinate time.
Identify proper time with the time measured by the local clock.
Identify coordinate time with the time measured by a distant observer.
Express the fundamental time dilation relationship.
The distant observer measures coordinate time as their proper time.
Solve for observed time in terms of proper time in the gravitational field.
Define frequency as the inverse of time period.
Calculate observed frequency using the time dilation relationship.
Define the proper frequency emitted in the gravitational field.
Obtain the gravitational frequency shift (redshift) formula.
